UPMC provides a wide variety of benefits to the communities we serve. Working in ways both large and small, we have implemented initiatives that continue to enhance the lives of individuals, communities, and the entire western Pennsylvania region. Some of those efforts such as the Pittsburgh Promise scholarship program for the Pittsburgh Public Schools and our support for medical education and research can be easily seen. Yet our work behind the scenes such as providing free or reduced-cost care, specialized services for our region s frail seniors, or our unwavering commitment to building and strengthening our local economy is equally compelling. reaChing ouT Through a sTruCTure of suCCess G. NICHOLAs BECKWITH III At UPMC, we take our role as a responsible citizen extremely seriously, and are proud of life-changing accomplishments that have improved the health of the community, built businesses, and provided a brighter tomorrow for future generations. Every year we refine our process for pinpointing community needs and responding with the right combinations of programs and resources. As an Integrated Delivery and Finance System (IDFS), we continue to amplify and apply the incredible expertise that exists within our organization, and use it to improve the delivery of outstanding health care to everyone we serve. In addition, we leverage our IDFS structure which includes our hospitals, our insurance infrastructure, and our community providers to enhance the health of individual western Pennsylvania communities, as well as the overall well-being of our region. The result is exceptional synergy among our insurance organization, health care providers, patients, and the communities western Pennsylvanians call home. We see great potential in our region s future, and are proud to step forward to do our part today, and in the years to come. 2 UPMC 2011 COMMUNITY BENEFITs REPORTConneCTing WiTh The real neeDs of our CoMMuniTies To ensure that our community efforts focus on the most pressing needs of the individuals and communities we serve, UPMC is now collaborating with the University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health to conduct a community health needs assessment (CHNA). Throughout our organization, we are reaching out to our community partners in systematic ways to determine their points of view on the most pressing issues and gain their insights on how we can best work together to address them. With this vital information in hand, we will have exceptional insight into community perspectives, and a roadmap to help us direct resources where services are most needed and the impact is most beneficial. Western Pennsylvania has great potential for a healthy and rewarding future. At UPMC, we will continue to provide the support individuals and communities can count on. To sharpen that skillset, the Aging Institute of UPMC Senior Services and the University of Pittsburgh has developed Ageless Wisdom, a class that allows clinicians, caregivers, and others throughout the region to walk in seniors shoes. While our people are all professionals, working with elderly residents is certainly a niche, and a different type of setting than they may be used to, says Vicki Loucks, director of a system of independent senior facilities. Loucks brought in the Aging Institute to train her staff at Redstone Highlands Senior Living Communities. Using ingenious aids such as eyeglasses that simulate a range of vision problems and devices that simulate age-associated mobility challenges, the program enables staff members to experience the personal situations of residents. It also positions them to provide better care for residents, and to catch medically associated changes early potentially avoiding hospitalization and the loss of independence.
